sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: A ferocious European heatwave heads north as the UK records temperatures never seen before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Fueled by the hot conditions, wildfires burn across France, Spain, Greece and Portugal, seeing thousands forced to flee their homes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The heatwave has also led to the spread of online misinformation and conspiracy theories. We'll have more in the cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And Russian President Vladimir Putin visits Iran for the first trip outside of the former Soviet Union since the start of the war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us. Well, people in Europe are scrambling for shade as a record-breaking heat wave is sweeping northwards across the continent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Extreme weather warnings are in place in France, with several regions recording their hottest ever days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Temperatures have soared in Spain and Portugal, causing over 1,000 deaths.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Belgium, too, has extended weather warnings to more parts of the country as the heatwave extends its reach further north.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: A major incident has been declared in London as fires broke out amid record-breaking temperatures in the capital of over 40 degrees Celsius.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Emergency services are dealing with blazes across the city, including on the outskirts of East London, where one house has been completely destroyed. London's Mayor Sadiq Khan describing the situation as fueled devastating wildfires in multiple countries, and firefighters are battling with deadly blazes in France, as well as Portugal, Greece and Spain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Emergency shelters have been established for the tens of thousands of people who've been forced to flee their homes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: In southwest France, wildfires have destroyed thousands of hectares of vegetation, as well as campsites, houses and restaurants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Local authorities reported that fires in the region were still progressing on several fronts well Francesca de Donato joins me now from Rome and among other roles she manages the Italian national heat health warning system Francesca great to have you with us thank you for being on the program now I know I'm stating the obvious here a little bit when I say that Italy is used to dealing with warmer summers but I'm just wondering from what you're seeing is there a sense that right now this is something out of the ordinary that this isn't an Italian summer as usual. Yes. Hi. Good evening. Thank you for having me. Yes it's it's been a very warm summer as it is as you say Italy is used to heat having me. Yes, it's been a very warm summer, as it is, as you say, Italy is used to heatwaves to some extent, but it's the third very extreme heatwave we've been experiencing, and it's only the middle of July, and widespread, and there have been very extents in terms of the areas covered geographically as well as the number of consecutive days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Today we issued level two or three warnings in 15 Italian cities, and it's bound to go up in the next few days to cover the whole country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And it's said to be lasting over 10 days as we speak now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So it is quite intense.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It's quite an anomalous summer, I would say, in terms of the extent of the actual heatwave.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now, I was just in Italy northern Italy myself a couple of weeks ago and I saw the way that Italians there dealt with the heat there were certainly precautions that they were taking but perhaps people who aren't familiar with that you could give them some tips about keeping themselves cool hydrated and the precautions that they should take with this kind of weather. Yeah I mean it's very easy to say that you don't suffer from the heat. Fortunately, more people than are aware of the risks of heat. They can be mild heat symptoms like just having heat cramps or heat stress, but they can turn into severe conditions as well, like a heat stroke or even hospital admissions or mortality increases that we've been experiencing over the last week. So there are similar precautions that should be taken among the general public but especially among those that are more susceptible to the health conditions during heat waves because they don't have accurate thermoregulation. So it's patients with chronic conditions such as cardiorespiratory disease, diabetes, kidney disease, who should be drinking much more, being aware of their health status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: If things do get worse, contact your GP or health services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It's important to stay out of the sun during the hottest hours of the day, to cool down just with water, not necessarily having a shower, but cool down with, you know, cool patches or things like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Try and keep your house cool as well, having natural ventilation and not going from very cold air-conditioned spaces to the outdoors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So try and be aware of the health conditions and the warnings that have been issued, the services that are in place in your city if you do need help and assistance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Most European countries have heat warning systems as well as heat adaptation plans, which do encourage specific measures for those most vulnerable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And there are services in place, both from social services to health services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So do get in touch with your local authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Right. I mean, all vital information, vital tips there, Francesca. But I think something that's so incredible in this moment is we're not just talking about vulnerable people, right? This can also be fit young people. I mean, heat stroke is something that can be very scary. it can also affect young people. What should people look out for in terms of heat strokes specifically, which I know can be very dangerous and what should they do about that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well yeah, I mean mostly is still the vulnerable that we should be looking after and making sure that they are checked upon and that there is the necessary attention towards these people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But even younger people, athletes, don't go out in the warmest hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Make sure you're drinking enough water and not alcoholic drinks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Ensure you have some protection and look out for those that are most at risk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And even young children, they get dehydrated easily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: that are most at risk. Even young children, they get dehydrated easily. Pregnant women as well should be aware of the heat and what they should be doing. Ask your health services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And again, you should be aware of the warnings that are issued and stay out of the heat mostly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And try and keep hydrated. that's one of the key aspects all right Francesca did Donato in Rome passing on some potentially life-saving advice there I wish you as cool as day as possible thank you so much for being with us thank you very much well the heat wave has also fueled online conspiracy theories and some social media users have claimed that the extreme temperatures are exaggerated by the scientific community. Matthew and the team of the Cube have been debunking these posts. Well Helena, for many people around Europe, many citizens, this week's heatwave has reinforced the reality of global warming. But other people online are still sharing climate denial content and claiming that this heatwave is being overplayed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They're trying to play down the seriousness of the hot temperatures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Some of the most concerning misinformation that we have found in the queue is being shared by people in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Some users, for example, claiming that this week's weather and this week's heat wave is no different from the famous summer of 1976, 46 years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: However, it's worth noting that the record temperature recorded in 1976 was 35.9 degrees Celsius.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Compare that to today at London Heathrow Airport, a preliminary temperature recorded of 40.2 degrees Celsius, a whole four degrees higher.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So it's not just normal this is not necessarily the same as 1976 climate denial content is no different we've had repeated warnings from scientists about the dangers of misinformation and what that does to governments trying to tackle global warming these warnings have been in place not just from authorities around the world but also within the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the reports issued by the IPCC.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And here in the Cube we spoke to one climate scientist who said that these continued denials of climate change and the impact of extreme weather was for him disheartening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I'm very disappointed that people would still start questioning the existence, never mind the importance of climate change as a driver for heat waves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: If you like, the gold standard for all of this should be what does the overwhelming majority of climate scientists say in their IPCC reports and not fictitious reports made up by people who often have no scientific background in the area.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And Helena, the overwhelming majority of climate scientists are pointing to the facts, the record temperatures in both France and the UK, as well as the grass and wildfires breaking out across the continent. Indeed, the chief of the UN's World Meteorological Organisation has also issued a stark message, saying that he hopes this week's heatwave will be a wake-up call, not just for governments, but also for voters on climate change.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Matthew and team, thank you so much. As we know, four degrees Celsius, literally worlds apart from the 70s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Well, while Europe contends with the current heatwave, Australia has published a report assessing the changing state of the environment in recent years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Australia has published a report assessing the changing state of the environment in recent years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And the report lists climate change, pollution and habitat loss as key factors which have left some ecosystems on the brink of collapse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Heather Donald reports now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Australia's 2021 state of the environment report is out and its findings are grim.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It says the country's environment is poor and deteriorating due to climate change and human activity. And the situation may be even worse once the consequences of recent environmental catastrophes are better known. The bushfires of 2019 and 2020 are still being felt today. Those bushfires were an ecological bomb ripping through southeastern Australia. They killed or displaced up to three billion creatures. They burnt over 80% of the greater Blue Mountains area, almost 60% of our Gondwana rainforests and more than 40% of the Stirling Range National Park. And they tipped clouds of sediment and ash into our waterways, leading to mass marine deaths.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: According to the report, Australia has lost more mammal species

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: than any other continent in the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Over 100 animals have been declared extinct or extinct in the wild.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: A primary reason is habitat destruction, caused often by natural catastrophes such as flooding and fires. The five-year report is putting pressure on the government to promise new laws and enforce them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Russian President Vladimir Putin has travelled to Tehran to meet his Iranian and Turkish counterparts in what is the second trip abroad since invading Ukraine. Now, as one of Moscow's few remaining allies, President Putin says that relations with Iran are strong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The conflict in Syria, grain exports and the war in Ukraine are set to dominate those talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now, the meeting comes amid Turkey's plan to launch a new military operation in northern Syria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: President Erdogan says Ankara and Tehran should continue to fight against terrorist organizations in solidarity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The two countries will also increase trade to the sum of some 29 billion euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has announced the nation's new chief of security following allegations that Russia has infiltrated his inner circle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The former head was suspended on Sunday for failing to root out treason in his department. Ukraine's Prosecutor General was also fired under a similar accusation. Zelensky says 651 cases have been opened into suspected collaboration between officials in Kyiv and Russian-occupied Ukraine. Well still to come, how long before 27 becomes 29, North Macedonia and Albania finally start EU membership talks after years of delay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: That is after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the program. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now, after years of delays, letdowns and even name changes, North Macedonia and Albania finally began EU membership talks today in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now, following a meeting with the two countries' prime ministers, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen thanked the leaders for their progress.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: For North Macedonia, the road to EU membership has faced many setbacks over the last 17 years with many compromises and changes being made along the way. Albania, meanwhile, has also been pushing for membership to the bloc since 2014. The strategic importance of the Western Balkan countries to the European Union has escalated over concerns of Moscow's growing influence in the region. We can cross over now to Brussels. We can bring in our correspondent, Shona Murray. Shona, good to see you. I mean, it feels like, well, it has taken years actually to get to this day, but it's really only just begun, hasn't it? How much longer until these two potentially become members of the European Union? Well, Helena, like that, we don't know. It could take a few years. It could take a few decades. It really depends on when these countries are able to transpose EU laws and regulations into their national statute books.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And that depends on those sovereign decisions by those countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: The EU member states here will be looking specifically about how committed they are to things like the rule of law, the European Court of Justice, Article 2 of the treaties supporting democratic values. And that's because countries like Hungary and Poland that came later into the EU have total disregard for those things and are causing huge problems, particularly Hungary, which is no longer regarded as a democracy by some. And the problem is that in some of the Western Balkans countries, you've seen the rise of the far right, you've seen the rise of illiberal politicians who don't support the rule of law and would cause huge trouble within the European Union, particularly in countries like Serbia, for example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Aleksandar Vucic, the president there, who's a huge supporter of Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: So this is why the enlargement, one of the reasons why the enlargement process has been so completely stalled and why some countries like France and others have rejected EU enlargement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But earlier on today, I caught up with Professor John O'Brennan from Maynooth University in Ireland, and I asked him a little bit about this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: One of the reasons for this, one of the key reasons, is that the people in power in these key capitals in the western balkans have managed to maintain themselves in power precisely because there's no prospect of their states becoming members of the european union if there was a concrete date to work to such as 2030, 2032. And the European Union made it absolutely clear that the demands that they make regarding reform are going to be properly overseen and properly scrutinized in a way that wasn't done, I think, sufficiently well previously.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I think that would make a key difference in the domestic politics of all those states, because you'd be saying that if you are not going to take rule of law issues seriously, if you continue to flirt with Vladimir Putin's regime, the price you're going to pay is being completely excluded from the integration process. So I think there's a symbiotic link between the degree of seriousness of the EU in setting a date or otherwise for membership and the pace of genuine reform that takes place in the region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: For far too long, many within the EU were content to just keep the Western Balkans at a remove.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They didn't really care about what Vucic, for example, was doing domestically in Serbia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That has got to change in my view.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: And one of the ways we do it, I think, is by the symbolism of cracking down on rule of law transgressions within the Union and making it very clear to those in power in the Western Balkans, they will not be allowed to do what Orban has been doing in the European Union since 2010. And that's EU law professor John O'Brennan on the European Commission's delicate balance of bringing new countries into the EU to allow for security, stability, prosperity, while ensuring that when they're in the EU that they abide by important matters like the rule of law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Well, Shona, just so many important points there in that interview.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Thanks for bringing it to us. Shona Murray there reporting from Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Well, now to the UK, where only three candidates are left in the race to become the next Tory leader.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And of course, with that, the next UK Prime Minister and those still in with a chance, a former Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, who won the latest round of voting, followed by Trade Minister Penny Mordaunt and Foreign Secretary Liz Truss. The next ballot is taking place on Wednesday and will leave only two candidates standing. They'll then face off in a long summer campaign leading up to a wider party vote with the final results announced on the 5th of September.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: France has announced a 9.7 billion euro bid to renationalise energy giant EDF.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Prime Minister Elisabeth Bonn had signalled that the state had the intention to regain total control of the company earlier this month. Now if successful, the French government, which already owns over 83% of the company will have free reign to direct the firm amid a growing energy crisis in Europe now Poland's government has also announced new measures to tackle the escalating energy crisis including coal subsidies but the fossil fuel friendly decision has raised concerns among ecologists Magdalena who Dik reports. Poland contains the largest number of houses heated by coal across the entire European continent. However, rising prices, the war in Ukraine and declining coal reserves have fueled fears of a looming energy crisis. We are in a situation where we probably have the lowest coal reserves available to us since World War II.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The basic problem we have with this type of coal for households is that there is simply no place to mine it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Coal burners across Poland use about 10 million tons a year to heat their homes, and only half of this is extracted in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The other half actually comes to us from Russia and partly from Kazakhstan. However, Russia has now stopped cargo trains from Kazakhstan, so this route is no longer available.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Krystyna Lesicka, who heats her house with a coal stove, is not concerned about the availability of the raw material for now, but she is concerned about the price.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: A year ago, when I paid, the price was about 146 euros. I also bought coal for 210 euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But now it's 420 euros. I have never paid that much. Never. If I only had my pension to live on, then I would have to spend my monthly pension on a ton of coal. And then, how would I live? What about the costs?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: A ton of coal is not enough for me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: I need to have 2.5 tons for the winter season, which is now over 837 euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: This is a lot of money. A lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In a bid to support the locals, the government has decided to lower carbon standards.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: But this has raised concerns among ecologists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Nowadays, the government is suspending these fairly low overall quality standards, telling mines and retailers to sell everything.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Standards haven't existed for 60 days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: These recently banned fuels are available for sale and they will probably become cheaper because they are composed of poor quality flow-tooconcentrates or silt, which contain large amounts of moisture, sulphur, heavy metals and ash. We are concerned that these fuels will simply be blended with other coals and sold. It will generate additional profits to both the mines and the mining sector, but will also create smog and more pollution this winter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The problem with coal has become a very sensitive topic in Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The government is trying to create aid programs to prevent a crisis before the winter season begins.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But as of today, no clear solution has been found.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Magdalena Hodownik for Euronews from Warsaw.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Coming up after the break, tempted by the clear blue lake waters often seen on Instagram.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: I know I am.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Well, in Switzerland, they are charging visitors for a dip that's making waves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: I'll tell you more in just a moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Welcome back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now, here's a question for you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Could too much hype on Instagram threaten Switzerland's hidden gems? Renowned as one of the country's most beautiful lakes, officials are too much hype on Instagram, threaten Switzerland's hidden gems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Renowned as one of the country's most beautiful lakes, officials are clamping down on visitors to Lake Calma, hoping to snap the crystal clear waters for themselves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Dawn has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The pearl of the Swiss Alps attracts thousands of tourists and locals alike every year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The turquoise waters of Lake Calma, coupled with this stunning mountainous backdrop, sits some 1,000 meters above sea level. However, the attraction now comes with a price tag.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It costs 19 francs, and I actually only wanted to bathe once, so I find it very expensive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, I thought it would be a little bit less, but when I could see the view from the top, and I saw it, I was like I was like oh okay I'll pay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We were passing through and we really wanted to see this. We didn't pay attention to the price but clearly it's not accessible to everyone. To further ensure an unforgettable guest experience a maximum of 1,700 ticket holders are allowed on site per day. This measure was introduced to place a cap on day visitors flocking to the area, attracted by the huge hype around the Blue Lake on Instagram.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's not that we want to exclude day guests, but through pricing we want to prevent too many of them from populating Lake Kauma compared to the guests we already have." Critics on social media have slammed the move as discriminatory and the charge a rip-off.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But some think it's necessary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We're not necessarily used to pricing a natural attraction in the Swiss or European context.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But if you look internationally, it's quite common.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Nevertheless, charging the equivalent of 19 euros, which is twice the price of Zorich swimming baths, is a step too far for many.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And the private company that leases and operates the lake is likely to profit, but also nature.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: You're up to date. Thanks for your company.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I'll see you soon.
